data.text: The star around which Earth and other planets orbit. It provides heat and light to Earth. It has a mean distance from Earth of about 150 million kilometers (93 million miles), a diameter of approximately 1,392,000 kilometers (865,000 miles), and a mass about 335,000 times that of Earth.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A star that is the center of a planetary system.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The radiant energy, especially heat and visible light, emitted by the sun; sunshine.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A sunlike object, representation, or design.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To expose to the sun's rays, as for warming, drying, or tanning.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To expose oneself or itself to the sun.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: (in the sun) In the public eye.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: (under the sun) On the earth; in the world.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To expose to the sun's rays; warm or dry in the sunshine; insolate: as, to <internalXref urlencoded="sun">sun</internalXref> cloth.
